etymology.description: 木(木) (mù, "tree") + 木(木) (mù, "tree") = multiple trees -> forest
etymology.interpretation: 林(林) (lín, "forest") uses the repetition of 木(木) (mù, "tree") to visually and conceptually represent a forest, which consists of many trees grouped together. This ideogram effectively captures the collective meaning through duplication.

examples.chinese: 我走进幽静的林(我走進幽靜的林)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zǒu jìn yōujìng de lín.
examples.english: I walked into the quiet forest.

examples.chinese: 孩子们在林中围成一圈(孩子們在林中圍成一圈)，嬉戏声此起彼伏(嬉戲聲此起彼伏)。
examples.pinyin: Háizimen zài lín zhōng wéi chéng yī quān, xīxì shēng cǐ qǐ bǐ fú.
examples.english: The children formed a circle in the forest, and their laughter echoed continuously.
